results.title: Dr. No (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Harry Saltzman, Albert R. Broccoli, Terence Young and Ken Adam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr.No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist plots to overtake the world but is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her first screen appearance in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme and elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder have become part of the James Bond legend.

results.title: Dr. No
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Harry Saltzman, Albert R. Broccoli, Terence Young and Ken Adam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr. No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist, is a member of the terrorist organisation SPECTRE, which plans to conquer the world. However, thanks to the daring of James Bond, Dr. No is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her screen debut in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme, elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder and the magnificent locations were present from this first film and have now become part of the James Bond legend.

Ursula Andress made her screen debut in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme, elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder and the magnificent locations were present from this first film and have now become part of the James Bond legend.

results.title: Dr. Elizabeth Kubler Ross
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Monday Conference”.
Dr Elizabeth Kubler-Ross explains her treatment of the problems surrounding death and dying. She also details ways of dealing with the particular problems involved in coming to terms with the death of a young child

results.title: Dr Terror's house of horror
results.creator_credit: Amicus Productions, Paul Stone and Freddy Frances
results.brief_description: During the 1960s and 70s, Amicus Productions were one of the most popular horror movie-making studios. “Dr Terror’s house of horror” was the first Amicus film, and with its portmanteau structure, features an array of supernatural settings. In a railway carriage sit five men; a mysterious doctor joins them and offers to tell their terrible fortunes. In them, a werewolf menaces a realtor; an art critic is terrorised by the severed hand of a disgruntled artist; a third man suspects his wife is a vampire; a jazz musician is pursued by a voodoo curse; a cottage is besieged by a monster vine. With its frightening narratives, and great cast, this is a wonderfully creepy classic horror experience. Also known as “Blood suckers”.

results.title: Dr Spock
results.brief_description: Presents the theories and practice of Dr. Benjamin Spock and his suggestions to parents for dealing with the problems, foibles and characteristics of children from infancy to the age of six.

results.title: Dr Seuss: The Cat in the Hat Comes Back
results.brief_description: The Cat in the Hat Comes Back - Sally and her brother soon learn that C A T spells trouble. This favourite story about the mischievous cat has delighted generations of children. “There’s a Wombat in my Pocket” - Do you suspect that there’s a nureau in the bureau? Find out what other fantastic creatures could be lurking in your home. “Fox in Socks” - The Fox in Socks presents his rubber tongue collection of brain numbing tongue twisters for kids of all ages.

results.title: Dr Seuss: One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish
results.brief_description: One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish - From there to here, from here to there, funny things are everywhere. A captivating Dr Seuss journey through the out-of-the-ordinary. “Oh the Things you can Think” - encourage your child’s imagination with this exuberant collection of made-up words, fanciful creatures, and creative ideas. “The Foot Book” - Clown feet, pig feet, small feet. Dr Seuss’s silly homage to the common foot.

results.title: Dr Seuss: How the Grinch stole Christmas
results.brief_description: Presented here are two adaptations of stories for children by the much loved Dr. Seuss: “How the Grinch stole Christmas” and “If I ran the zoo”. Narrated by Walter Matthau, “How the Grinch stole Christmas” is the story of the people from Who-ville…”Every Who in Who-ville liked Christmas a lot…But the Grinch, who lived just north of Who-ville, did not!”. “If I ran the zoo” tells a tale of young McGrew and his fantastical animals like the scraggle-foot Mulligatawny and the elephant cat,”Young McGrew’s made his mark. He’s built a zoo better than Noah’s whole ark”. Narrated by Brett Ambler.

results.title: Dr Seuss: how Grinch stole Christmas
results.brief_description: Dr. Seuss’s famous story. The nasty Grinch decides to stop Christmas from coming to the town of Who-Ville by stealing all the Christmas presents that Santa has just delivered, only to discover the true meaning of Christmas is not about presents. Narrated by Boris Karloff. Also features ‘Horton Hears a Who’.
